title: How to export my InDesign file to look like a real book - Quora

response.answer_text: If your book is in one continuous document file, add a cover page with a blank page in front of the first page of text in the book. At the end of your document, add a blank page, then add another blank page to create the back cover on the last page. Export to PDF. Once exported, you can open it as a book. If using multiple documents to create a book, create a ‘BOOK’ under the document setup tab. This will save a booking box, as I call it. Add each single file document using the plus sign. For my books, I have a different document file for the cover, title page, intro pages, chapters, back cover. Once these are loaded into the book box (.indb / InDesign Book File) save this, then click on the top far right corner of the box to access the pull down menu. Ask the computer to save as a PDF & you’re done! Even if you have just one entire document file, create a indb book to accompany it. Create this new book the same way as mentioned earlier; setting up a new book, under document set up. This allows you to be able to preflight it (to check for problems), and then package it for print. Packaging for print allows InDesign to create a folder of all the documents, fonts, and links used to create the document — and have this ready to hand off to a printer who is printing/publishing your book.

Well, there is the simple, low-tech method I’ve used before: Design two pages of your book.Print out those pages.Pick a real book you have.If necessary, crop your printed pages to the same size as the pages in that book.Open the book and lay the two pages in it, covering the two exposed pages of the book, and tucking the pages into the center so they appear to be part of the book.Take a picture of it.Here’s an example where I did exactly that. In this case, I was using Word, because it was a preliminary for our first book, and we hadn’t gotten InDesign yet, but there’s no reason why it wouldn’t work with absolutely any layout or word processing program:  I did it on a black background, then increased the contrast in a photo editing program.

You can save out your InDesign file as a PDF (with spreads) Then you can use one of the Photoshop SCripts from PSD Covers to create a mockup. The SCripts are split into 2 tasks. One part sets up the template where you add your pages to the template. The second part does all the 3D mockup work for you automatically. PSDCovers • Photoshop Mockups For Product Presentation Book Archives • PSDCovers

From within in design, choose and save as .jpg file at full size. Then using whatever mockup you want to use with photoshop, you would open a smart object and place your page within the spread as you like. It's fairly simple, but requires that you know a little about working with photoshop.

Search for "free book mockup psd" on google and you will get tons of options.Open the psd file with photoshop and replace ur design pages with the existing ones and you will have what you are looking for!
